accessibility.header: Accessibility statement for Applying for and Accepting a Refugee Integration Loan
accessibility.intro: This accessibility statement applies to the 'Apply for a refugee integration loan' and 'Accepting your integration loan' services. It does not cover related pages on the www.gov.uk website, which has its own accessibility statement.
accessibility.intro-p2: This website is run by the Home Office. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website. For example, that means you should be able to:
accessibility.intro-p2-li1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
accessibility.intro-p2-li2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
accessibility.intro-p2-li3: navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
accessibility.intro-p2-li4: navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
accessibility.intro-p2-li5: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
accessibility.intro-p3-pre-link: We have also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
accessibility.intro-p3-post-link: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
accessibility.reporting-header: Reporting accessibility problems with this website
accessibility.reporting-p1: We are always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we're not meeting accessibility requirements, contact us at
accessibility.reporting-p2-link: Read tips on contacting organisations about inaccessible websites.
accessibility.enforcement-p1-pre-link: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the 'accessibility regulations'). If you're not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
accessibility.enforcement-p1-link: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS).
accessibility.enforcement-p2: If you are in Northern Ireland and are not happy with how we respond to your complaint you can contact the Equalities Commission for Northern Ireland who are responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the 'accessibility regulations') in Northern Ireland.
accessibility.technical-info-header: Technical information about this website's accessibility
accessibility.technical-info-p1: The Home Office is committed to making its website accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
accessibility.compliance-p1: This website is partially compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.2 AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.
accessibility.non-accessible-p1: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
accessibility.non-compliance-p1: We are aware of and working to address the following issues. We will update this statement with timelines about when we will resolve them a month after this statement’s publication date.
accessibility.non-compliance-p2: On the 'Have you ever been convicted of a crime in the UK' page and the 'You and your partner's combined monthly income' page on some form elements, an aria-labelledby or aria-describedby reference exists but the target for the reference does not exist. Screen readers will not pick up on the relationship between the words and the input and so may progress without completing the action. This does not meet WCAG 1.3.1 Info and relationships and WCAG 4.1.2 Name, role, value standards and guidelines.
accessibility.non-compliance-p3: On the 'How would you like us to contact you' page on several form elements an aria attribute has been allowed where it should not be allowed. This could mean hidden reveals within form elements are missed by screen readers.  This does not meet the WCAG 4.1.2 Name, role, value standards and guidelines.
accessibility.non-compliance-p5: The session timeout of 30 minutes cannot be changed and the user is not alerted when it is running out. This for each individual page of the form, not the form overall. This does not meet WCAG 2.2 - Enough Time.
accessibility.non-compliance-p6: If you find an issue that we have yet to identify, please contact us using one of the routes described in the ‘Reporting accessibility problems with this website’ section of this statement.
accessibility.disproportionate-burden-p1: At this time, we have not made any disproportionate burden claims.
accessibility.outside-scope-header: Content that's not within the scope of the accessibility regulations
accessibility.outside-scope-p1: At this time, this service does not contain any content that is exempt from the regulations
accessibility.preparation-p1: This statement was prepared on 18 September 2024. It was last reviewed on 05 December 2024.
accessibility.preparation-p2: This website was last tested on 05 December 2024. The test was carried out internally by the Home Office.
accessibility.preparation-p3: We tested the service based on a user's ability to complete key journeys. All parts of the chosen journeys were tested, including documents. Journeys were chosen on a number of factors including usage statistics, risk assessments and subject matter.

feedback.detailsHeader: Leave your details so we can contact you if we need to

confirmation.helpUsImproveParagraph: Home Office needs your help to ensure our services work well for the people who need them.
confirmation.helpUsImproveParagraph2: You can sign up to take part in research in person and online. You do not need to be good with computers or the internet to join.
confirmation.helpUsImproveParagraph3: If you helped someone fill in the form, we would like to talk to you so we can improve services for you and others who provide support.
confirmation.helpUsImproveParagraphVoucher: We may give you a voucher for taking part.
confirmation.findOutMore: Find out more about what's involved

improve-our-services.needsYourHelp: Home Office needs your help to improve and to make sure our services work well for the people who need them.
improve-our-services.toJoin: To sign up and help, you must:
improve-our-services.bulletUkEu: live in the UK or EU
improve-our-services.chooseToTakePart: In the UK you can choose to take part in user research in person and online. If you live in the EU, it will be online.
improve-our-services.voucher: We may give you a voucher for taking part.
improve-our-services.youCanSayNo: You can always say no to an invite and you can unsubscribe at any time.
improve-our-services.whatsInvolvedParagraph: When you sign up, you’ll get a short survey to fill in about you and how you use computers. Your answers will help make sure you get invited to research that’s relevant to you and will not be shared with anyone else.
improve-our-services.notGoodWithComputers: You do not have to be good with computers or the internet to take part.
improve-our-services.youMightBeAsked: Once you’ve signed up, you might be asked to:
improve-our-services.bulletTalkToResearchers: talk to our researchers about how you’ve interacted with government in the past
improve-our-services.bulletVisit: visit a government building near you
improve-our-services.bulletMeetResearchers: let our researchers meet you at home or work
improve-our-services.preferToMeet: You can say if you’d prefer to meet researchers or do online research when you sign up.
improve-our-services.bulletYouVisit: you to come to a government or public building
improve-our-services.bulletVisitHomeWork: to visit you at home or work
improve-our-services.researchTime: This type of research can take between 30 minutes and 1 hour.
improve-our-services.recordResearch: We will ask if we can record the research. We do this to help us remember what you did and what you said. We may share the recording with other teams at Home Office, but we never share your personal details. It is up to you if you want to agree to this.
improve-our-services.onlineTask: We will give you an online task. You must provide your own internet connection and computer, smartphone or tablet.
improve-our-services.researchTimeOnline: This type of research can take between 30 minutes and 1 hour depending on the task.
improve-our-services.maybeVouchers: There may be vouchers to be offered, depending on the research.
improve-our-services.takePartResearch: If you take part in research online, you’ll be given a task to do on a service. You do not need to travel anywhere for these sessions but you’ll need your own internet connection, computer, phone or tablet to take part. The sessions usually last 30 minutes.
improve-our-services.contactEmail: You can contact the Home Office research team at
improve-our-services.moreInformation: for more information or to update your details.
